Topic 1: floating point number systems

pitfalls of computation

eg. compute e−5.5e^{-5.5}e−5.5 using 5-digit arithmetic

recall:

ex=1+x1!+x22!+x33!+...e^x=1+\frac{x}{1!}+\frac{x^2}{2!}+\frac{x^3}{3!}+... ex=1+1!x​+2!x2​+3!x3​+...

so

e−5.5=1+−5.51!+(−5.5)22!+(−5.5)33!+...≈1−5.5+15.125−27.730+...=0.0026363\begin{aligned} e^{-5.5} &= 1+\frac{-5.5}{1!}+\frac{(-5.5)^2}{2!}+\frac{(-5.5)^3}{3!}+... \\ &\approx 1-5.5+15.125-27.730+...=0.0026363 \end{aligned} e−5.5​=1+1!−5.5​+2!(−5.5)2​+3!(−5.5)3​+...≈1−5.5+15.125−27.730+...=0.0026363​

e−5.5=1e5.5=(1+5.51!+5.522!+5.533!+...)−1≈(1+5.5+15.125+27.730)−1=0.0040865\begin{aligned} e^{-5.5} &= \frac{1}{e^{5.5}}=(1+\frac{5.5}{1!}+\frac{5.5^2}{2!}+\frac{5.5^3}{3!}+...)^{-1} \\ &\approx (1+5.5+15.125+27.730)^{-1}=0.0040865 \end{aligned}e−5.5​=e5.51​=(1+1!5.5​+2!5.52​+3!5.53​+...)−1≈(1+5.5+15.125+27.730)−1=0.0040865​

why?

eg. let In=∫01xnx+αdxI_n=\int_0^1\frac{x^n}{x+\alpha}dxIn​=∫01​x+αxn​dx

note

In=∫01xn+xn−1α−xn−1αx+αdx=∫01xn−1(x+α)x+αdx−∫01αxn−1x+αdx=∫01xn−1dx−α∫01xn−1x+αdx=1n−αIn−1\begin{aligned} I_n&=\int_0^1\frac{x^n+x^{n-1}\alpha-x^{n-1}\alpha}{x+\alpha}dx \\ &=\int_0^1\frac{x^{n-1}(x+\alpha)}{x+\alpha}dx-\int_0^1\frac{\alpha x^{n-1}}{x+\alpha}dx \\ &=\int_0^1x^{n-1}dx-\alpha\int_0^1\frac{x^{n-1}}{x+\alpha}dx \\ &=\frac{1}{n}-\alpha I_{n-1} \end{aligned} In​​=∫01​x+αxn+xn−1α−xn−1α​dx=∫01​x+αxn−1(x+α)​dx−∫01​x+ααxn−1​dx=∫01​xn−1dx−α∫01​x+αxn−1​dx=n1​−αIn−1​​

where I0=log⁡(1+αα)I_0=\log(\frac{1+\alpha}{\alpha})I0​=log(α1+α​).

import numpy as np

def In(alpha, n):
    I = np.log((1 + alpha) / alpha)
    for n in np.arange(1, n+1):
        I = 1./n - alpha*I
    return I

In(0.5, 100)  # 0.006644371123395131
In(2, 100)  # 6058010443603.891 weird

Strange since In=∫01xnx+αdx≤∫01xn1dx=1n+1I_n=\int_0^1\frac{x^n}{x+\alpha}dx\le\int_0^1\frac{x^n}{1}dx=\frac{1}{n+1}In​=∫01​x+αxn​dx≤∫01​1xn​dx=n+11​ if 0≤x≤10\le x\le 10≤x≤1 and α>1\alpha>1α>1. and we should have I100≤1101I_{100}\le\frac{1}{101}I100​≤1011​.

if InExact=InApprox+ErrnI_n^{\mathrm{Exact}}=I_n^\mathrm{Approx}+\mathrm{Err}_nInExact​=InApprox​+Errn​ then,

Err=InE−InA=(1n−αIn−1E)−(1n−αIn−1A)=−α(In−1E−In−1A)=−αErrn−1∣Errn∣=∣α∣n∣Err0∣\begin{aligned} \mathrm{Err}&=I_n^E-I_n^A\\ &=\left(\frac{1}{n}-\alpha I_{n-1}^E\right)-\left(\frac{1}{n}-\alpha I_{n-1}^A\right) \\ &=-\alpha(I_{n-1}^E-I_{n-1}^A) \\ &=-\alpha\mathrm{Err}_{n-1} \\ |\mathrm{Err}_n|&=|\alpha|^n|\mathrm{Err}_0| \end{aligned} Err∣Errn​∣​=InE​−InA​=(n1​−αIn−1E​)−(n1​−αIn−1A​)=−α(In−1E​−In−1A​)=−αErrn−1​=∣α∣n∣Err0​∣​

  • so if ∣α∣<1|\alpha|<1∣α∣<1 then ∣Err∣→0|\mathrm{Err}|\to 0∣Err∣→0, the computation is stable.
  • if ∣α∣>1|\alpha|>1∣α∣>1 then ∣Err∣→∞|\mathrm{Err}|\to \infty∣Err∣→∞, the computation is unstable.

float point numbers

  • computers can represent numbers by fixed point (int) and floating point (real)
  • always in normalized form
  • issues:
    • density: only keeps a finite number of digits
    • range: only keeps a finite range of exponent

see. CS251

t: significant digits, L: lower bound, U: upper bound

single precision F(b=2, t=24, L=-126, U=127):

  • one bit sign, 23 digits for precision, 8 digits for exponent

double precision F(b=2, t=53, L=-1022, U=1023):

  • one bit sign, 52 digits for precision, 11 digits for exponent

note implicit leading 1 in precision is used.

special number:

  • 0: 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000
  • eg. suppose in F(10, 8, -35, 35)
    • largest number is 0.99999999 * 10^35
    • smallest number: 0.10000000 * 10^-35
    • anything larger: overflow
    • anything smaller: underflow (typically rounded to 0)

defn. if x=±0.x1...xtxt+1...∗βpx=\plusmn0.x_1...x_tx_{t+1}...*\beta^px=±0.x1​...xt​xt+1​...∗βp, then fl(x)=±0.x1...xt∗βp\mathrm{fl}(x)=\plusmn0.x_1...x_t*\beta^pfl(x)=±0.x1​...xt​∗βp, ie we use truncation. relative error is

δx=fl(x)−xx\delta_x=\frac{\mathrm{fl}(x)-x}{x} \\ δx​=xfl(x)−x​

note fl(x)=(1+δ)x\mathrm{fl}(x)=(1+\delta)xfl(x)=(1+δ)x.

we have

δx=−0.0...0xt+1...x1.x2...xtxt+1...β∣δx∣≤0.xt+1...∗β−t1β≤β1−t=E\begin{aligned} \delta_x&=\frac{-0.0...0x_{t+1}...}{x_1.x_2...x_tx_{t+1}...}\beta\\ |\delta_x|&\le\frac{0.x_{t+1}...*\beta^{-t}}{1}\beta\\ &\le\beta^{1-t} = E \end{aligned} δx​∣δx​∣​=x1​.x2​...xt​xt+1​...−0.0...0xt+1​...​β≤10.xt+1​...∗β−t​β≤β1−t=E​

this quantity is called machine epsilon E.

  • it is independent of the numbers involved
  • relates to the number of significant digits in the result (t)
  • eg. a result is correct to roughly s digits if relative error ≈ 10^-s

it also often defined as the smallest positive number E such that fl(1.0+E)>1.0\mathrm{fl}(1.0+E)>1.0fl(1.0+E)>1.0, and also often called unit round-off error.

if we use rounding we could get E=12β1−tE=\frac{1}{2}\beta^{1-t}E=21​β1−t.

arithmetics

to do arithmetics, we do

  • put numbers into a computer (fl())
  • do normal arithmetics as two reals
  • put number back into the computer

eg. suppose x and y are real numbers, then error of addition:

x⊕y=fl(fl(x)+fl(y))=(fl(x)+fl(y))(1+δz)\begin{aligned} x\oplus y&=\mathrm{fl}(\mathrm{fl}(x)+\mathrm{fl}(y)) \\ &=(\mathrm{fl}(x)+\mathrm{fl}(y))(1+\delta_z) \end{aligned} x⊕y​=fl(fl(x)+fl(y))=(fl(x)+fl(y))(1+δz​)​

∣x+y−x⊕yx+y∣≤∣x+y−(x(1+δx)+y(1+δy))(1+δz)∣∣x+y∣=∣xδx+yδy+xδz+yδz+xδxδz+yδyδz∣∣x+y∣≤∣x∣∣δx∣+∣y∣∣δy∣+∣x∣∣δz∣+∣y∣∣δz∣+∣x∣∣δx∣∣δz∣+∣y∣∣δy∣∣δz∣∣x+y∣=(∣x∣+∣y∣)∣x+y∣(2E+E2)\begin{aligned} \left|\frac{x+y-x\oplus y}{x+y}\right|&\le \frac{\left|x+y-(x(1+\delta_x)+y(1+\delta_y))(1+\delta_z)\right|}{|x+y|} \\ &=\frac{|x\delta_x+y\delta_y+x\delta_z+y\delta_z+x\delta_x\delta_z+y\delta_y\delta_z|}{|x+y|}\\ &\le \frac{|x||\delta_x|+|y||\delta_y|+|x||\delta_z|+|y||\delta_z|+|x||\delta_x||\delta_z|+|y||\delta_y||\delta_z|}{|x+y|}\\ &=\frac{(|x|+|y|)}{|x+y|}(2E+E^2) \end{aligned} ∣∣​x+yx+y−x⊕y​∣∣​​≤∣x+y∣∣x+y−(x(1+δx​)+y(1+δy​))(1+δz​)∣​=∣x+y∣∣xδx​+yδy​+xδz​+yδz​+xδx​δz​+yδy​δz​∣​≤∣x+y∣∣x∣∣δx​∣+∣y∣∣δy​∣+∣x∣∣δz​∣+∣y∣∣δz​∣+∣x∣∣δx​∣∣δz​∣+∣y∣∣δy​∣∣δz​∣​=∣x+y∣(∣x∣+∣y∣)​(2E+E2)​

  • if x and y are of the same sign then |x+y|=|x|+|y| then the relative error ≤(2E+E2)\le(2E+E^2)≤(2E+E2)
  • if x and y are of the opposite sign and nearly the same size then |x+y| is very small, so the relative error is very large (this is called catastrophic cancellation, why the first way of computing e^-5.5 is wrong)

Week 2. May 17

Polynomial interpolation

interpolation: given n points (x's distinct), find a nice function that go through the points.

  • nice means polynomial (of degree at most n-1)
  • nice means spline
  • points might not be distinct

vandermonde system

with n points (x1,y1),...,(xn,yn)(x_1,y_1),...,(x_n,y_n)(x1​,y1​),...,(xn​,yn​) and distinct xix_ixi​'s and a polynomial p(x) of degree at most n-1 satisfying p(x1)=y1,...,p(xn)=ynp(x_1)=y_1,...,p(x_n)=y_np(x1​)=y1​,...,p(xn​)=yn​ results in n equations with n unknowns. In matrix form this is

[1x1x12...x1n−11x2x22...x2n−1......1xnxn2...xnn−1][c1c2...cn]=[y1y2...yn]\begin{bmatrix} 1& x_1& x_1^2& ...& x_1^{n-1}\\ 1& x_2& x_2^2& ...& x_2^{n-1}\\ ...& & & & ...\\ 1& x_n& x_n^2& ...& x_n^{n-1} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} c_1\\c_2\\...\\c_n \end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix} y_1\\y_2\\...\\y_n \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​11...1​x1​x2​xn​​x12​x22​xn2​​.........​x1n−1​x2n−1​...xnn−1​​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​c1​c2​...cn​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​y1​y2​...yn​​⎦⎤​

the matrix of coefficients is called vandermande matrix V.

we have ∣V(x1,...,xn)∣=∏i<j(xi−xj)|V(x_1,...,x_n)|=\prod_{i<j}(x_i-x_j)∣V(x1​,...,xn​)∣=∏i<j​(xi​−xj​). when x's are distinct then V is nonsigular. the system has a unique solution that always exists.

eg. have four points (1, 1), (-1, 7), (2, 1), (3, -5), find p(x)=c1+c2x+c3x2+c4x3p(x)=c_1+c_2x+c_3x^2+c_4x^3p(x)=c1​+c2​x+c3​x2+c4​x3.
substitute the points note we have

p(1)=c1+c2+c3+c4=1p(−1)=c1−c2+c3−c4=7p(2)=c1+2c2+4c3+8c4=1p(3)=c1+3c2+9c3+27c4=−5\begin{aligned} p(1)=\quad&c_1&+c_2&+c_3&+c_4&=1\\ p(-1)=\quad&c_1&-c_2&+c_3&-c_4&=7\\ p(2)=\quad&c_1&+2c_2&+4c_3&+8c_4&=1\\ p(3)=\quad&c_1&+3c_2&+9c_3&+27c_4&=-5 \end{aligned} p(1)=p(−1)=p(2)=p(3)=​c1​c1​c1​c1​​+c2​−c2​+2c2​+3c2​​+c3​+c3​+4c3​+9c3​​+c4​−c4​+8c4​+27c4​​=1=7=1=−5​

use gaussian elimination to get p(x)=1−2x+3x2−x3p(x)=1-2x+3x^2-x^3p(x)=1−2x+3x2−x3.

lagrange interpolation

lagrange form: given distinct points (x1,y1),...,(xn,yn)(x_1,y_1),...,(x_n,y_n)(x1​,y1​),...,(xn​,yn​) and distinct xix_ixi​'s define

Li(x)=(x−x1)...(x−xi−1)(x−xi+1)...(x−xn)(xi−x1)...(xi−xi−1)(xi−xi+1)...(xi−xn)=∏j∈[n]−{i}x−xjxi−xjL_i(x)=\frac{(x-x_1)...(x-x_{i-1})(x-x_{i+1})...(x-x_n)}{(x_i-x_1)...(x_i-x_{i-1})(x_i-x_{i+1})...(x_i-x_n)}=\prod_{j\in[n]-\{i\}}\frac{x-x_j}{x_i-x_j} Li​(x)=(xi​−x1​)...(xi​−xi−1​)(xi​−xi+1​)...(xi​−xn​)(x−x1​)...(x−xi−1​)(x−xi+1​)...(x−xn​)​=j∈[n]−{i}∏​xi​−xj​x−xj​​

then the interpolating polynomial is p(x)=y1L1(x)+...+ynLn(x)p(x)=y_1L_1(x)+...+y_nL_n(x)p(x)=y1​L1​(x)+...+yn​Ln​(x).

proof.

  • for each iii degree of LiL_iLi​ is n-1
  • Li(xj)=0L_i(x_j)=0Li​(xj​)=0 if i≠ji\ne ji=j
  • Li(xi)=1L_i(x_i)=1Li​(xi​)=1
  • so p(xi)=yip(x_i)=y_ip(xi​)=yi​, p is the unique interpolating polynomial. □\square□

cubic hermite interpolation

given 2 points (x1,y1),(x2,y2)(x_1,y_1), (x_2,y_2)(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​) and two derivative values s1,s2s_1,s_2s1​,s2​. find a polynomial S(x)S(x)S(x) of degree at most 3 with

S(x1)=y1,S(x2)=y2S′(x1)=s1,S′(x2)=s2S(x_1)=y_1,S(x_2)=y_2\\ S'(x_1)=s_1,S'(x_2)=s_2 S(x1​)=y1​,S(x2​)=y2​S′(x1​)=s1​,S′(x2​)=s2​

then the polynomial is

S(x)=a+b(x−x1)+c(x−x1)2+d(x−x1)3S(x)=a+b(x-x_1)+c(x-x_1)^2+d(x-x_1)^3 S(x)=a+b(x−x1​)+c(x−x1​)2+d(x−x1​)3

which is 4 eqs with 4 unknowns. the solution is

a=y1b=s1c=3y′−2s1−s2Δxd=s1+s2−2y′Δx2\begin{aligned} a&=y_1\\ b&=s_1\\ c&=\frac{3y'-2s_1-s_2}{\Delta x}\\ d&=\frac{s_1+s_2-2y'}{\Delta x^2} \end{aligned} abcd​=y1​=s1​=Δx3y′−2s1​−s2​​=Δx2s1​+s2​−2y′​​

where Δx=x2−x1,Δy=y2−y1,y′=ΔyΔx\Delta x=x_2-x_1,\Delta y=y_2-y_1,y'=\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}Δx=x2​−x1​,Δy=y2​−y1​,y′=ΔxΔy​.

Week 3. May 25

issues with poly interpolation

  • fits point correctly, but might not be so correct elsewhere
  • not easy to compute (numerically) for large n

eg.

Spline interpolation

piecewise polynomial interpolation: given n points (x1,y1),...,(xn,yn)(x_1,y_1),...,(x_n,y_n)(x1​,y1​),...,(xn​,yn​) with xix_ixi​'s distinct. we want to find a piecewise polynomial S(x) s.t.

S(x)={S1(x),x1≤x≤x2...Sn−1(x),xn−1≤x≤xnS(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} S_1(x)&,x_1\le x\le x_2 \\ ...\\ S_{n-1}(x)&,x_{n-1}\le x \le x_n \end{matrix}\right. S(x)=⎩⎨⎧​S1​(x)...Sn−1​(x)​,x1​≤x≤x2​,xn−1​≤x≤xn​​

with each Si(x)S_i(x)Si​(x) a polynomial (usually same degrees) and S(x)=yiS(x)=y_iS(x)=yi​.

linear piecewise polynomial: given n such points, each Si(x)S_i(x)Si​(x) is line joining (xi,yi)(x_i,y_i)(xi​,yi​) to (xi+1,yy+1)(x_{i+1},y_{y+1})(xi+1​,yy+1​) (a poly with degree <= 1).

  • problem: not continuous

cubic spline interpolation

given n points (x1,y1),...,(xn,yn)(x_1,y_1),...,(x_n,y_n)(x1​,y1​),...,(xn​,yn​) with xix_ixi​'s distinct. we want to find a piecewise polynomial S(x) s.t.

S(x)={S1(x),x1≤x≤x2...Sn−1(x),xn−1≤x≤xnS(x)=\left\{\begin{matrix} S_1(x)&,x_1\le x\le x_2 \\ ...\\ S_{n-1}(x)&,x_{n-1}\le x \le x_n \end{matrix}\right. S(x)=⎩⎨⎧​S1​(x)...Sn−1​(x)​,x1​≤x≤x2​,xn−1​≤x≤xn​​

with each Si(x)S_i(x)Si​(x) a polynomial of degree at most 3 satisfying

  • S(xi)=yiS(x_i)=y_iS(xi​)=yi​
  • S(x)∈C2S(x)\in C^2S(x)∈C2

remark. cubic spline interpolation is not unique.

  • n points => n-1 intervals, and each interval has 4 unknowns (deg 3 poly) => 4(n-1) unknowns
  • we have 2(n-1)+2(n-2) conditions
    • for every interval, S(xi)=yiS(x_i)=y_iS(xi​)=yi​ on both sides => 2(n-1) conditions
    • S' continuous (n-2 joining points, their derivative has to match) => (n-2) conditions
    • S'' continuous => (n-2) conditions
  • so 2 more unknowns than conditions □\square□

we can use boundary conditions to let the result be unique.

defn. (natural): S′′(x1)=S′′(xn)=0S''(x_1)=S''(x_n)=0S′′(x1​)=S′′(xn​)=0.

defn. (clamped): S′(x1)=s1S'(x_1)=s_1S′(x1​)=s1​ and S′(xn)=snS'(x_n)=s_nS′(xn​)=sn​ where s1,sns_1,s_ns1​,sn​ are given in advance.

defn. (periodic): S′(x1)=S′(xn)S'(x_1)=S'(x_n)S′(x1​)=S′(xn​) and S′′(x1)=S′′(xn)S''(x_1)=S''(x_n)S′′(x1​)=S′′(xn​) (assuming y1=yny_1=y_ny1​=yn​).

defn. (not-a-knot): S1′′′(x2)=S2′′′(x2)S_1'''(x_2)=S_2'''(x_2)S1′′′​(x2​)=S2′′′​(x2​) and Sn−1′′′(xn−1)=Sn′′′(xn−1)S_{n-1}'''(x_{n-1})=S_n'''(x_{n-1})Sn−1′′′​(xn−1​)=Sn′′′​(xn−1​).

  • forcing first two polys are same, and last two polys are same

eg. by using cubic hermite for each interval [xi,xi+1][x_i,x_{i+1}][xi​,xi+1​], we have

Si(x)=ai+bi(x−xi)+ci(x−xi)2+di(x−xi)3S_i(x)=a_i+b_i(x-x_i)+c_i(x-x_i)^2+d_i(x-x_i)^3 Si​(x)=ai​+bi​(x−xi​)+ci​(x−xi​)2+di​(x−xi​)3

and Si(xi)=yi,Si(xi+1)=yi+1,Si′(xi)=si,Si′(xi+1)=si+1S_i(x_i)=y_i,S_i(x_{i+1})=y_{i+1},S_i'(x_i)=s_i,S_i'(x_{i+1})=s_{i+1}Si​(xi​)=yi​,Si​(xi+1​)=yi+1​,Si′​(xi​)=si​,Si′​(xi+1​)=si+1​, where si,si+1s_i,s_{i+1}si​,si+1​ are unknowns. from here we know SSS interpolates the points and the derivative is continuous. to let second derivative be continuous, we also have Si′′(xi+1)=Si+1′′(xi+1)S_i''(x_{i+1})=S_{i+1}''(x_{i+1})Si′′​(xi+1​)=Si+1′′​(xi+1​) for i=1,...,n−2i=1,...,n-2i=1,...,n−2. note

Si′′(x)=2ci+6di(x−xi),Si+1′′(x)=2ci+1+6di+1(x−xi+1)S_i''(x)=2c_i+6d_i(x-x_i),\quad S_{i+1}''(x)=2c_{i+1}+6d_{i+1}(x-x_{i+1}) Si′′​(x)=2ci​+6di​(x−xi​),Si+1′′​(x)=2ci+1​+6di+1​(x−xi+1​)

plugging in x=xi+1x=x_{i+1}x=xi+1​ we get (delta_i is from i to i+1)

ci+3diΔxi=ci+13yi′−2si−si+1Δxi+3si+si+1−2yi′Δxi2Δxi=3yi+1−2si+1−si+2Δxi+1Δxi+1si+2(Δxi+Δxi+1)si+1+Δxisi+2=3(Δxi+1yi′+Δxiyi+1′)c_i+3d_i\Delta x_i=c_{i+1}\\ \frac{3 y_{i}^{\prime}-2 s_{i}-s_{i+1}}{\Delta x_{i}}+3 \frac{s_{i}+s_{i+1}-2 y_{i}'}{\Delta x_{i}^{2}}\Delta x_i=\frac{3 y_{i+1}-2 s_{i+1}-s_{i+2}}{\Delta x_{i+1}}\\ \Delta x_{i+1} s_{i}+2\left(\Delta x_{i}+\Delta x_{i+1}\right) s_{i+1}+\Delta x_{i} s_{i+2}=3\left(\Delta x_{i+1} y_{i}^{\prime}+\Delta x_{i} y_{i+1}^{\prime}\right) ci​+3di​Δxi​=ci+1​Δxi​3yi′​−2si​−si+1​​+3Δxi2​si​+si+1​−2yi′​​Δxi​=Δxi+1​3yi+1​−2si+1​−si+2​​Δxi+1​si​+2(Δxi​+Δxi+1​)si+1​+Δxi​si+2​=3(Δxi+1​yi′​+Δxi​yi+1′​)

which are n-2 equations for n unknowns.

suppose we want natural boundary conditions: S′′(x1)=S′′(xn)=0S''(x_1)=S''(x_n)=0S′′(x1​)=S′′(xn​)=0.

this is the same as S1′′(x1)=Sn−1′′(xn)=0S_1''(x_1)=S_{n-1}''(x_n)=0S1′′​(x1​)=Sn−1′′​(xn​)=0. combine the equations for {S1′′,c1,d1}\{S_1'',c_1,d_1\}{S1′′​,c1​,d1​} and {Sn−1′′,cn−1,dn−1}\{S_{n-1}'',c_{n-1},d_{n-1}\}{Sn−1′′​,cn−1​,dn−1​} we have additional two eqs.

3y1′=2s1+s2,3yn−1′=2sn+sn−13y_1'=2s_1+s_2,\quad 3y_{n-1}'=2s_n+s_{n-1} 3y1′​=2s1​+s2​,3yn−1′​=2sn​+sn−1​

note the coefficient matrix looks like diagonal and each row has 2 or 3 non-zero values, and it takes O(n) to determine s1,...,sns_1,...,s_ns1​,...,sn​.

parametric curves

given n points (x1,y1),...,(xn,yn)(x_1,y_1),...,(x_n,y_n)(x1​,y1​),...,(xn​,yn​) with xix_ixi​'s not distinct. we look for a curve C(t)=(x(t),y(t)),t1≤t≤tnC(t)=(x(t), y(t)),t_1\le t\le t_nC(t)=(x(t),y(t)),t1​≤t≤tn​ that goes through the points. steps:

  1. get parameter values t1,...,tnt_1,...,t_nt1​,...,tn​
  2. separate x and y into two distinct interpolation problems:
    • find x(t) that interpolates (t1,x1),...,(tn,xn)(t_1,x_1),...,(t_n,x_n)(t1​,x1​),...,(tn​,xn​)
    • find y(t) that interpolates (t1,y1),...,(tn,yn)(t_1,y_1),...,(t_n,y_n)(t1​,y1​),...,(tn​,yn​)

how to find parameter values?

  1. use t1=0,t2=1,...,tn=n−1t_1=0,t_2=1,...,t_n=n-1t1​=0,t2​=1,...,tn​=n−1
  2. use arc length: t1=0,ti+1=ti+(xi+1−xi)2+(yi+1−yi)2t_1=0,t_{i+1}=t_i+\sqrt{(x_{i+1}-x_i)^2+(y_{i+1}-y_i)^2}t1​=0,ti+1​=ti​+(xi+1​−xi​)2+(yi+1​−yi​)2​

to plot the curve C(t):

  1. determine a set of parameter values τ0,...,τN,N>>n\tau_0,...,\tau_{N},N>>nτ0​,...,τN​,N>>n
  2. plug τi\tau_iτi​ into x(t),y(t)x(t),y(t)x(t),y(t) to get χi,φi\chi_i,\varphi_iχi​,φi​'s, then plot the points (χi,φi)(\chi_i,\varphi_i)(χi​,φi​).

general first order ODE

defn. if dydt=f(t,y)\frac{dy}{dt}=f(t,y)dtdy​=f(t,y) or y′(t)=f(t,y(t))y'(t)=f(t,y(t))y′(t)=f(t,y(t)) where t0≤t≤tft_0\le t\le t_ft0​≤t≤tf​, f is a function of two variables t and y, then fff is called system dynamics function.

{dydt=f(t,y)y(t0)=a\left\{\begin{aligned} \frac{d\mathbf{y}}{dt}&=\mathbf{f}(t,\mathbf{y}) \\ \mathbf{y}(t_0)&=\mathbf{a} \end{aligned}\right. ⎩⎨⎧​dtdy​y(t0​)​=f(t,y)=a​

forward euler method

consider first order ODE

{y′(t)=f(t,y(t))y(t0)=α\left\{\begin{aligned} y'(t)&=f(t,y(t))\\ y(t_0)&=\alpha \end{aligned}\right. {y′(t)y(t0​)​=f(t,y(t))=α​

suppose at t=tk−1t=t_{k-1}t=tk−1​, we have yk−1≈y(tk−1)y_{k-1}\approx y(t_{k-1})yk−1​≈y(tk−1​). at t=tkt=t_kt=tk​, we use yk−1y_{k-1}yk−1​ to compute yky_kyk​.

using geometric

let hk−1=tk−tk−1h_{k-1}=t_k-t_{k-1}hk−1​=tk​−tk−1​ be the time step size. by ode, we have y′(tk−1)=f(tk−1,y(tk−1))y'(t_{k-1})=f(t_{k-1},y(t_{k-1}))y′(tk−1​)=f(tk−1​,y(tk−1​)), we have approximation y′(tk−1)=slope of y at tk−1≈yk−yk−1hk−1y'(t_{k-1})=\text{slope of y at } t_{k-1}\approx\frac{y_k-y_{k-1}}{h_{k-1}}y′(tk−1​)=slope of y at tk−1​≈hk−1​yk​−yk−1​​. we assume our approximation is correct so we replace y(tk−1)y(t_{k-1})y(tk−1​) by yk−1y_{k-1}yk−1​ so the approximation is:

yk−yk−1hk−1=f(tk−1,yk−1)yk=yk−1+hk−1f(tk−1,yk−1)\begin{aligned} \frac{y_k-y_{k-1}}{h_{k-1}}&=f(t_{k-1},y_{k-1})\\ y_k&=y_{k-1}+h_{k-1}f(t_{k-1},y_{k-1}) \end{aligned} hk−1​yk​−yk−1​​yk​​=f(tk−1​,yk−1​)=yk−1​+hk−1​f(tk−1​,yk−1​)​

this requires one function evaluation for each time step.

using taylor expansion

local truncation error: assume timestep is constant h and we have a method computing yky_kyk​. then yk−y(tk)=O(hp+1)y_k-y(t_k)=O(h^{p+1})yk​−y(tk​)=O(hp+1). the bigger p the better.

by taylor, we have y(tk)=y(tk−1+hk−1)=y(tk−1)+hk−1y′(tk−1)+hk−122!y′′(ϵk)y(t_k)=y(t_{k-1}+h_{k-1})=y({t_{k-1}})+h_{k-1}y'(t_{k-1})+\frac{h^2_{k-1}}{2!}y''(\epsilon_k)y(tk​)=y(tk−1​+hk−1​)=y(tk−1​)+hk−1​y′(tk−1​)+2!hk−12​​y′′(ϵk​) where tk−1<ϵk<tkt_{k-1}<\epsilon_k<t_ktk−1​<ϵk​<tk​. substitute the ode we have y(tk)=y(tk−1)+hk−1f(tk−1,y(tk−1))+O(h2)y\left(t_{k}\right)=y\left(t_{k-1}\right)+h_{k-1} f\left(t_{k-1}, y\left(t_{k-1}\right)\right)+O(h^{2})y(tk​)=y(tk−1​)+hk−1​f(tk−1​,y(tk−1​))+O(h2). use the approximation y(tk−1)→yk−1,y(tk)→yky(t_{k-1})\rightarrow y_{k-1},y(t_k)\rightarrow y_ky(tk−1​)→yk−1​,y(tk​)→yk​ we get the result. and y(tk)−yk=O(h2)y(t_k)-y_k=O(h^2)y(tk​)−yk​=O(h2).

trapezoid method

algo.

y0=αyk=yk−1+hk−12(f(tk−1,yk−1)+f(tk,yk))\begin{aligned} y_0&=\alpha\\ y_k&=y_{k-1}+\frac{h_{k-1}}{2}(f(t_{k-1},y_{k-1})+f(t_k,y_k)) \end{aligned} y0​yk​​=α=yk−1​+2hk−1​​(f(tk−1​,yk−1​)+f(tk​,yk​))​

we have to solve for yky_kyk​ at each step.

using taylor

note by taylor

y(tk)=y(tk−1)+hy′(tk−1)+h22!y′′(tk−1)+h33!y′′′(ϵk)y′(tk)=y′(tk−1)+hy′′(tk−1)+h22!y′′′(α)y(t_k)=y(t_{k-1})+hy'(t_{k-1})+\frac{h^2}{2!}y''(t_{k-1})+\frac{h^3}{3!}y'''(\epsilon_k)\\ y'(t_k)=y'(t_{k-1})+hy''(t_{k-1})+\frac{h^2}{2!}y'''(\alpha) y(tk​)=y(tk−1​)+hy′(tk−1​)+2!h2​y′′(tk−1​)+3!h3​y′′′(ϵk​)y′(tk​)=y′(tk−1​)+hy′′(tk−1​)+2!h2​y′′′(α)

isolate hy′′hy''hy′′ we have hy′′(tk−1)=y′(tk)−y′′(tk−1)−h22!y′′′(α)hy''(t_{k-1})=y'(t_k)-y''(t_{k-1})-\frac{h^2}{2!}y'''(\alpha)hy′′(tk−1​)=y′(tk​)−y′′(tk−1​)−2!h2​y′′′(α), so

y(tk)=y(tk−1)+hy′(tk−1)+h2!(y′(tk)−y′(tk−1)−h22!y′′′(α))+h33!y′′′(ϵk)=y(tk−1)+h2!(y′(tk−1)+y′(tk))+O(h3)=y(tk−1)+h2!(f(tk−1,y(tk−1))+f(tk,y(tk)))+O(h3)\begin{aligned} y(t_k)&=y(t_{k-1})+hy'(t_{k-1})+\frac{h}{2!}(y'(t_k)-y'(t_{k-1})-\frac{h^2}{2!}y'''(\alpha))+\frac{h^3}{3!}y'''(\epsilon_k)\\ &=y(t_{k-1})+\frac{h}{2!}(y'(t_{k-1})+y'(t_k))+O(h^3)\\ &=y(t_{k-1})+\frac{h}{2!}(f(t_{k-1},y(t_{k-1}))+f(t_k,y(t_k)))+O(h^3) \end{aligned} y(tk​)​=y(tk−1​)+hy′(tk−1​)+2!h​(y′(tk​)−y′(tk−1​)−2!h2​y′′′(α))+3!h3​y′′′(ϵk​)=y(tk−1​)+2!h​(y′(tk−1​)+y′(tk​))+O(h3)=y(tk−1​)+2!h​(f(tk−1​,y(tk−1​))+f(tk​,y(tk​)))+O(h3)​

use the approximation y(tk−1)→yk−1,y(tk)→yky(t_{k-1})\rightarrow y_{k-1},y(t_k)\rightarrow y_ky(tk−1​)→yk−1​,y(tk​)→yk​ we get the result.

modified euler method

consider first order ODE

{y′(t)=f(t,y(t))y(t0)=α\left\{\begin{aligned} y'(t)&=f(t,y(t))\\ y(t_0)&=\alpha \end{aligned}\right. {y′(t)y(t0​)​=f(t,y(t))=α​

algo. approximate derivative at any point by taking average slope at starting point and approximated endpoint:

y0=αyk∗=yk−1+hk−1f(tk−1,yk−1)yk=yk−1+hk−12(f(tk−1,yk−1)+f(tk,yk∗))\begin{aligned} y_0&=\alpha\\ y_k^*&=y_{k-1}+h_{k-1}f(t_{k-1},y_{k-1})\\ y_k&=y_{k-1}+\frac{h_{k-1}}{2}(f(t_{k-1},y_{k-1})+f(t_k,y_k^*)) \end{aligned} y0​yk∗​yk​​=α=yk−1​+hk−1​f(tk−1​,yk−1​)=yk−1​+2hk−1​​(f(tk−1​,yk−1​)+f(tk​,yk∗​))​

using taylor

as before:

y(tk)=y(tk−1)+h2!(f(tk−1,y(tk−1))+f(tk,y(tk)))+O(h3)=y(tk−1)+h2(f(tk−1,y(tk−1)+f(tk,yk∗)))+h2(−f(tk,yk∗)+f(tk,y(tk)))+O(h3)\begin{aligned} y(t_k)&=y(t_{k-1})+\frac{h}{2!}(f(t_{k-1},y(t_{k-1}))+f(t_k,y(t_k)))+O(h^3)\\ &=y(t_{k-1})+\frac{h}{2}(f(t_{k-1},y(t_{k-1})+f(t_k,y^*_k)))+\frac{h}{2}(-f(t_k,y^*_k)+f(t_k,y(t_k)))+O(h^3) \end{aligned} y(tk​)​=y(tk−1​)+2!h​(f(tk−1​,y(tk−1​))+f(tk​,y(tk​)))+O(h3)=y(tk−1​)+2h​(f(tk−1​,y(tk−1​)+f(tk​,yk∗​)))+2h​(−f(tk​,yk∗​)+f(tk​,y(tk​)))+O(h3)​

since from forward euler we have y(tk)−yk∗=O(h2)y(t_k)-y^*_k=O(h^2)y(tk​)−yk∗​=O(h2), so from taylor of f(tk,y(tk))f(t_k,y(t_k))f(tk​,y(tk​)) as function of y: f(tk,y(tk))=f(tk,yk∗)+O(y(tk)−yk∗)=f(tk,yk∗)+O(h2)f(t_k,y(t_k))=f(t_k,y^*_k)+O(y(t_k)-y^*_k)=f(t_k,y^*_k)+O(h^2)f(tk​,y(tk​))=f(tk​,yk∗​)+O(y(tk​)−yk∗​)=f(tk​,yk∗​)+O(h2). hence

y(tk)=y(tk−1)+h2(f(tk−1,y(tk−1))+f(tk,yk∗))+h2O(h2)+O(h3)=y(tk−1)+h2(f(tk−1,y(tk−1))+f(tk,yk∗))+O(h3)\begin{aligned} y(t_k)&=y(t_{k-1})+\frac{h}{2}(f(t_{k-1},y(t_{k-1}))+f(t_k,y^*_k))+\frac{h}{2}O(h^2)+O(h^3)\\ &=y(t_{k-1})+\frac{h}{2}(f(t_{k-1},y(t_{k-1}))+f(t_k,y^*_k))+O(h^3) \end{aligned} y(tk​)​=y(tk−1​)+2h​(f(tk−1​,y(tk−1​))+f(tk​,yk∗​))+2h​O(h2)+O(h3)=y(tk−1​)+2h​(f(tk−1​,y(tk−1​))+f(tk​,yk∗​))+O(h3)​

local truncation error

  • LTE for forward euler is is O(h2)O(h^2)O(h2)
  • LTE for trapezoid is O(h3)O(h^3)O(h3)
  • LTE for modified euler is O(h3)O(h^3)O(h3)

in general

given yn=y_n=yn​= formula in yn,yn−1,...y_n,y_{n-1},...yn​,yn−1​,..., to determine the LTE

  1. replace all yky_kyk​ by the actual values y(tk)y(t_k)y(tk​) (assume formula is correct)
  2. compare taylor of y(tn)y(t_n)y(tn​) with taylor at tnt_ntn​ and at tn−1t_{n-1}tn−1​
    • remember f(tk,y(tk))=y′(tk)f(t_k,y(t_k))=y'(t_k)f(tk​,y(tk​))=y′(tk​) and has a taylor expansion

eg. what is error of yk=yk−1+h4f(tk−2,yk−2)+3h4f(tk,yk)y_k=y_{k-1}+\frac{h}{4}f(t_{k-2},y_{k-2})+\frac{3h}{4}f(t_k,y_k)yk​=yk−1​+4h​f(tk−2​,yk−2​)+43h​f(tk​,yk​).

  1. replace:

    y(tk)=y(tk−1)+h4f(tk−2,y(tk−2))+3h4f(tk,y(tk))=y(tk−1)+h4y′(tk−2)+3h4y′(tk) \begin{aligned} y(t_k)&=y\left(t_{k-1}\right)+\frac{h}{4} f\left(t_{k-2}, y\left(t_{k-2}\right)\right)+\frac{3 h}{4} f\left(t_{k}, y\left(t_{k}\right)\right) \\ &=y\left(t_{k-1}\right)+\frac{h}{4} y^{\prime}\left(t_{k-2}\right)+\frac{3 h}{4} y^{\prime}\left(t_{k}\right) \end{aligned} y(tk​)​=y(tk−1​)+4h​f(tk−2​,y(tk−2​))+43h​f(tk​,y(tk​))=y(tk−1​)+4h​y′(tk−2​)+43h​y′(tk​)​

  2. expand centered around tk−1t_{k-1}tk−1​

    y′(tk)=y′(tk−1)+hy′′(tk−1)+h22!y′′′(tk−1)+...y′(tk−2)=y′(tk−1)−hy′′(tk−1)+h22!y′′′(tk−1)+...y'(t_k)=y'(t_{k-1})+hy''(t_{k-1})+\frac{h^2}{2!}y'''(t_{k-1})+...\\ y'(t_{k-2})=y'(t_{k-1})-hy''(t_{k-1})+\frac{h^2}{2!}y'''(t_{k-1})+...\\ y′(tk​)=y′(tk−1​)+hy′′(tk−1​)+2!h2​y′′′(tk−1​)+...y′(tk−2​)=y′(tk−1​)−hy′′(tk−1​)+2!h2​y′′′(tk−1​)+...

  3. plug in and see where there is a difference between our result and expansion of formula

    y(tk)=y(tk−1)+hy′(tk−1)+h22y′′(tk−1)+h32y′′′(tk−1)+...y(tk)=y(tk−1)+hy′(tk−1)+h22y′′(tk−1)+h36y′′′(tk−1)+...(actual formula)y\left(t_{k}\right)=y\left(t_{k-1}\right)+hy^{\prime}\left(t_{k-1}\right)+\frac{h^{2}}{2}y^{\prime \prime}\left(t_{k-1}\right)+\frac{h^{3}}{2}y^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(t_{k-1}\right)+...\\ y\left(t_{k}\right)=y\left(t_{k-1}\right)+hy^{\prime}\left(t_{k-1}\right)+\frac{h^{2}}{2}y^{\prime \prime}\left(t_{k-1}\right)+\frac{h^{3}}{6}y^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(t_{k-1}\right)+...\text{(actual formula)} y(tk​)=y(tk−1​)+hy′(tk−1​)+2h2​y′′(tk−1​)+2h3​y′′′(tk−1​)+...y(tk​)=y(tk−1​)+hy′(tk−1​)+2h2​y′′(tk−1​)+6h3​y′′′(tk−1​)+...(actual formula)

it is O(h^3).

timestamp control

how to determine if numerical method likely gives a correct answer?

  • obvious: run the method with timestamp h, then run again with timestamp h/2. compare answers.

we can combine forward euler and modified euler:

ykFE=y(tk)+Ah2+O(h3)ykME=y(tk)+O(h3)y_k^\mathrm{FE}=y(t_k)+Ah^2+O(h^3)\\ y_k^\mathrm{ME}=y(t_k)+O(h^3) ykFE​=y(tk​)+Ah2+O(h3)ykME​=y(tk​)+O(h3)

so we have

local error≈∣Ah2∣=∣ykFE−ykME∣\text{local error}\approx|Ah^2|=|y_k^\mathrm{FE}-y_k^\mathrm{ME}| local error≈∣Ah2∣=∣ykFE​−ykME​∣

in general, at every timestamp consider two rules, one for order p, one for order p+1, the local error is the difference between two methods: |local error|=∣Ahp∣=∣yk(1)−yk(2)∣|Ah^p|=|y_k^{(1)}-y_k^{(2)}|∣Ahp∣=∣yk(1)​−yk(2)​∣.

if error is too big then reduce timestep h by 2 and repeat.

eg. a common method: runge kutta methods (RKF45)

k1=hf(tn,yn)k2=hf(tn+h4,yn+k14)k3=hf(tn+3h8,yn+3k132+9k232)k4=hf(tn+12h13,yn+1932k12197−7200k22197+7296k32197)k5=hf(tn+h,yn+439k1216−8k2+3680k3513−845k44104)k6=hf(tn+h2,yn−8k127+2k2−3544k32565+1859k44104−11k540)yn+1∗=yn+25k1216+1408k32565+2197k44104−k55 with error O(h4)yn+1=yn+16k1135+6656k312825+28561k456430−9k550+2k655 with error O(h5)\begin{aligned} &k_{1}=h f\left(t_{n}, y_{n}\right) \\ &k_{2}=h f\left(t_{n}+\frac{h}{4}, y_{n}+\frac{k_{1}}{4}\right) \\ &k_{3}=h f\left(t_{n}+\frac{3 h}{8}, y_{n}+\frac{3 k_{1}}{32}+\frac{9 k_{2}}{32}\right) \\ &k_{4}=h f\left(t_{n}+\frac{12 h}{13}, y_{n}+\frac{1932 k_{1}}{2197}-\frac{7200 k_{2}}{2197}+\frac{7296 k_{3}}{2197}\right) \\ &k_{5}=h f\left(t_{n}+h, y_{n}+\frac{439 k_{1}}{216}-8 k_{2}+\frac{3680 k_{3}}{513}-\frac{845 k_{4}}{4104}\right) \\ &k_{6}=h f\left(t_{n}+\frac{h}{2}, y_{n}-\frac{8 k_{1}}{27}+2 k_{2}-\frac{3544 k_{3}}{2565}+\frac{1859 k_{4}}{4104}-\frac{11 k_{5}}{40}\right) \\ &y_{n+1}^{*}=y_{n}+\frac{25 k_{1}}{216}+\frac{1408 k_{3}}{2565}+\frac{2197 k_{4}}{4104}-\frac{k_{5}}{5} \text { with error } O\left(h^{4}\right) \\ &y_{n+1}=y_{n}+\frac{16 k_{1}}{135}+\frac{6656 k_{3}}{12825}+\frac{28561 k_{4}}{56430}-\frac{9 k_{5}}{50}+\frac{2 k_{6}}{55} \text { with error } O\left(h^{5}\right) \end{aligned} ​k1​=hf(tn​,yn​)k2​=hf(tn​+4h​,yn​+4k1​​)k3​=hf(tn​+83h​,yn​+323k1​​+329k2​​)k4​=hf(tn​+1312h​,yn​+21971932k1​​−21977200k2​​+21977296k3​​)k5​=hf(tn​+h,yn​+216439k1​​−8k2​+5133680k3​​−4104845k4​​)k6​=hf(tn​+2h​,yn​−278k1​​+2k2​−25653544k3​​+41041859k4​​−4011k5​​)yn+1∗​=yn​+21625k1​​+25651408k3​​+41042197k4​​−5k5​​ with error O(h4)yn+1​=yn​+13516k1​​+128256656k3​​+5643028561k4​​−509k5​​+552k6​​ with error O(h5)​

timestamp control (2)

instead of dividing by 2, we can also do:

suppose we require ∣Ahp∣=∣yk(1)−yk(2)∣|Ah^p|=|y_k^{(1)}-y_k^{(2)}|∣Ahp∣=∣yk(1)​−yk(2)​∣ < TOL, at next step we can change the timestep to some h2h_2h2​:

yk+1(1)=y(tk+1)+Ah2p+O(h2p+1)yk+1(2)=y(tk+1)+O(h2p+1)y_{k+1}^{(1)}=y(t_{k+1})+Ah_2^p+O(h_2^{p+1})\\ y_{k+1}^{(2)}=y(t_{k+1})+O(h_2^{p+1}) yk+1(1)​=y(tk+1​)+Ah2p​+O(h2p+1​)yk+1(2)​=y(tk+1​)+O(h2p+1​)

now again we want local error = ∣Ah2p∣=h2php∣yk(1)−yk(2)∣|Ah_2^p|=\frac{h_2^p}{h^p}|y_k^{(1)}-y_k^{(2)}|∣Ah2p​∣=hph2p​​∣yk(1)​−yk(2)​∣ < TOL. this implies we can use h2<(TOL∣yk(1)−yk(2)∣h)1ph_2<\left(\frac{\mathrm{TOL}}{|y_k^{(1)}-y_k^{(2)}|}h\right)^\frac{1}{p}h2​<(∣yk(1)​−yk(2)​∣TOL​h)p1​.

stability

eg. the system dynamic function is y′(t)=−λy(t)y'(t)=-\lambda y(t)y′(t)=−λy(t) and y(t0)=y0y(t_0)=y_0y(t0​)=y0​. if we use forward euler to solve it, we have

yk=yk−1+hf(tk−1,yk−1)=yk−1+h⋅(−λyk−1)=yk−1(1−hλ)=...=y0(1−hλ)k\begin{aligned} y_k&=y_{k-1}+hf(t_{k-1},y_{k-1})\\ &=y_{k-1}+h\cdot(-\lambda y_{k-1})\\ &=y_{k-1}(1-h\lambda)\\ &=...\\ &=y_0(1-h\lambda)^k \end{aligned} yk​​=yk−1​+hf(tk−1​,yk−1​)=yk−1​+h⋅(−λyk−1​)=yk−1​(1−hλ)=...=y0​(1−hλ)k​

true solution is y(t)=y0e−λty(t)=y_0e^{-\lambda t}y(t)=y0​e−λt (goes to 0 as t -> inf). so method is stable when ∣1−hλ∣<1|1-h\lambda|<1∣1−hλ∣<1, or h<2λh<\frac{2}{\lambda}h<λ2​.

  • when using modified euler method, condition is also h<2λh<\frac{2}{\lambda}h<λ2​.
  • using backward euler (yk+1=yk+hf(tk+1,yk+1)y_{k+1}=y_{k}+h f\left(t_{k+1}, y_{k+1}\right)yk+1​=yk​+hf(tk+1​,yk+1​)) and trapezoid it is always stable.

event function

defn. event function is a function which changes sign.

  • how to tell numerical solver when to stop? trigger an event
  • event is triggered when event function changes sign, the solver can use it to decide whether to stop or continue

eg. predator catches prey: Event(predator, prey) = |dist(predator, prey)| - ϵ.

eg. we shoot a golf ball with some initial speed. in the middle of the field there is a wall that goes up and down (h = Acos(wt+y)). whenever ball hits the wall, it stops; whenever it hits the group, it also stops. Event(ball, barrier) = |dist(top of barrier to ball)| - ϵ and = |height of ball| - ϵ. link

fourier analysis

reviews of algebra:

  • (e2jπ/N)N=1(e^{2j\pi/N})^N=1(e2jπ/N)N=1.
  • eja=cos⁡a+jsin⁡ae^{ja}=\cos a+ j\sin aeja=cosa+jsina
  • cos⁡a=eja+e−ja2,sin⁡a=e−ja−eja2j\cos a=\frac{e^{ja}+e^{-ja}}{2},\sin a=\frac{e^{-ja}-e^{ja}}{2}jcosa=2eja+e−ja​,sina=2e−ja−eja​j
  • akcos⁡a+bksin⁡a=(ak2−bk2j)eja+(ak2+bk2j)e−jaa_k\cos a+b_k\sin a=(\frac{a_k}{2}-\frac{b_k}{2}j)e^{ja}+(\frac{a_k}{2}+\frac{b_k}{2}j)e^{-ja}ak​cosa+bk​sina=(2ak​​−2bk​​j)eja+(2ak​​+2bk​​j)e−ja
  • akcos⁡ϕ+bksin⁡ϕ=ak2+bk2cos⁡(ϕ+θ),tan⁡θ=−baa_k\cos \phi+b_k\sin \phi=\sqrt{a_k^2+b_k^2}\cos(\phi+\theta),\tan\theta=-\frac{b}{a}ak​cosϕ+bk​sinϕ=ak2​+bk2​​cos(ϕ+θ),tanθ=−ab​
  • if W=e2jπ/NW=e^{2j\pi/N}W=e2jπ/N
    • ∑k=0N−1Wkr={N,Wr=1⇔r=00,r≠0\sum_{k=0}^{N-1}W^{kr}=\left\{\begin{aligned}N,&W^r=1\Leftrightarrow r=0\\0,& r\neq 0\end{aligned}\right.∑k=0N−1​Wkr={N,0,​Wr=1⇔r=0r=0​
    • WWW is the N-th root of unity
    • W2,...,WN−1W^2,...,W^{N-1}W2,...,WN−1 are all N-th root of unity too

defn. fourier series of f(t) is f(t)=a0+a1cos⁡(qt)+b1sin⁡(qt)+a2cos⁡(2qt)+b2sin⁡(2qt)+...=∑k≥0(akcos⁡(kqt)+bksin⁡(kqt))f(t)=a_0+a_1\cos(qt)+b_1\sin(qt)+a_2\cos(2qt)+b_2\sin(2qt)+...=\sum_{k\ge 0}(a_k\cos(kqt)+b_k\sin(kqt))f(t)=a0​+a1​cos(qt)+b1​sin(qt)+a2​cos(2qt)+b2​sin(2qt)+...=∑k≥0​(ak​cos(kqt)+bk​sin(kqt)) where q (=2πT\frac{2\pi}{T}T2π​) is a constant factor.

  • ak,bka_k,b_kak​,bk​, or ak2+bk2\sqrt{a_k^2+b_k^2}ak2​+bk2​​ measure amount of function/data that repeats k times.

defn. we can write f(t)=∑k=−∞∞ckejktf(t)=\sum_{k=-\infty}^\infty c_ke^{jkt}f(t)=∑k=−∞∞​ck​ejkt, where c0=a0,ck=ak2−bk2j,c−k=ak2+bk2jc_0=a_0,c_k=\frac{a_k}{2}-\frac{b_k}{2}j,c_{-k}=\frac{a_k}{2}+\frac{b_k}{2}jc0​=a0​,ck​=2ak​​−2bk​​j,c−k​=2ak​​+2bk​​j for k > 0.

  • modulus of ckc_kck​ gives amplitude of given frequency of wave
  • argument of ckc_kck​ gives that frequency's phase

defn. given N points f0,...,fN−1f_0,...,f_{N-1}f0​,...,fN−1​, discrete fourier transform is the N values F0,...,FN−1F_0,...,F_{N-1}F0​,...,FN−1​ where Fk=1N(f0+W−kf1+W−2kf2+...+W−(N−1)kfN−1)=1N∑n=0N−1W−nkfnF_k=\frac{1}{N}(f_0+W^{-k}f_1+W^{-2k}f_2+...+W^{-(N-1)k}f_{N-1})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}W^{-nk}f_nFk​=N1​(f0​+W−kf1​+W−2kf2​+...+W−(N−1)kfN−1​)=N1​∑n=0N−1​W−nkfn​, and W=e2πj/NW=e^{2\pi j/N}W=e2πj/N.

  • note F0=1N∑n=0N−1fnF_0=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}f_nF0​=N1​∑n=0N−1​fn​ is the average
  • inverse fourier transform: fk=F0+WkF1+...=∑n=0N−1WnkFnf_k=F_0+W^kF_1+...=\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}W^{nk}F_nfk​=F0​+WkF1​+...=∑n=0N−1​WnkFn​

proof of inverse dft: the dft as matrix operation:

1N[111⋯11W−1W−2⋯W−(N−1)⋮⋮⋮⋯⋮1W−(N−1)W−2(N−1)⋯W−(N−1)(N−1)][f0f1⋮fN−1]=[F0F1⋮FN−1]\frac{1}{N}\left[\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 1 & 1 & \cdots & 1 \\ 1 & W^{-1} & W^{-2} & \cdots & W^{-(N-1)} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \cdots & \vdots \\ 1 & W^{-(N-1)} & W^{-2(N-1)} & \cdots & W^{-(N-1)(N-1)} \end{array}\right]\begin{bmatrix} f_{0} \\ f_{1} \\ \vdots \\ f_{N-1} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} F_{0} \\ F_{1} \\ \vdots \\ F_{N-1} \end{bmatrix} N1​⎣⎡​11⋮1​1W−1⋮W−(N−1)​1W−2⋮W−2(N−1)​⋯⋯⋯⋯​1W−(N−1)⋮W−(N−1)(N−1)​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​f0​f1​⋮fN−1​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​F0​F1​⋮FN−1​​⎦⎤​

the inverse dft as matrix operation:

[111⋯11WW2⋯W(N−1)⋮⋮⋮⋯⋮1WN−1W2(N−1)⋯W(N−1)(N−1)][F0F1⋮FN−1]=[f0f1⋮fN−1]\left[\begin{array}{ccccc} 1 & 1 & 1 & \cdots & 1 \\ 1 & W & W^{2} & \cdots & W^{(N-1)} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \cdots & \vdots \\ 1 & W^{N-1} & W^{2(N-1)} & \cdots & W^{(N-1)(N-1)} \end{array}\right]\begin{bmatrix} F_{0} \\ F_{1} \\ \vdots \\ F_{N-1} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} f_{0} \\ f_{1} \\ \vdots \\ f_{N-1} \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​11⋮1​1W⋮WN−1​1W2⋮W2(N−1)​⋯⋯⋯⋯​1W(N−1)⋮W(N−1)(N−1)​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​F0​F1​⋮FN−1​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​f0​f1​⋮fN−1​​⎦⎤​

we want to show the two operations are inverses. their product should have 1 entries on diagonal and 0 otherwise, use the algebra review above. □\square□

eg. suppose all N points are 1, then:

  • F0=1F_0=1F0​=1
  • Fk=1N∑n=0N−1W−nk=1N(1−W−Nk1−W−k)=0F_k=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}W^{-nk}=\frac{1}{N}(\frac{1-W^{-Nk}}{1-W^{-k}})=0Fk​=N1​∑n=0N−1​W−nk=N1​(1−W−k1−W−Nk​)=0

eg. suppose fk=2kf_k=2^kfk​=2k, then Fk=1N∑n=0N−1(2W−k)n=1N(1−(2W−k)N1−2W−k)=1N(1−2N1−2W−k)F_k=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}(2W^{-k})^n=\frac{1}{N}(\frac{1-(2W^{-k})^N}{1-2W^{-k}})=\frac{1}{N}(\frac{1-2^N}{1-2W^{-k}})Fk​=N1​∑n=0N−1​(2W−k)n=N1​(1−2W−k1−(2W−k)N​)=N1​(1−2W−k1−2N​) (note denominator cannot be 0 since W−k≠12W^{-k}\neq\frac{1}{2}W−k=21​).

Week 7. June 21

meaning of dft

given N equally spaced samples of a function f(t) over 0 to 2π2\pi2π, this implies we should keep only N coefficients from the fourier series of f(t):

c−N/2+1,...c−1,c0,c1,...,cN/2c_{-N/2+1},...c_{-1},c_0,c_1,...,c_{N/2} c−N/2+1​,...c−1​,c0​,c1​,...,cN/2​

where ∣c−n∣=∣cn∣=an2+bn22|c_{-n}|=|c_n|=\frac{\sqrt{a_n^2+b_n^2}}{2}∣c−n​∣=∣cn​∣=2an2​+bn2​​​ is the information about f(t) of frequency k. note ∣c0∣,∣cN/2∣|c_0|,|c_{N/2}|∣c0​∣,∣cN/2​∣ are special. we can approximate the fourier series (which is infinite sum) using these N numbers (we lose some info):

f(t)≈∑k=−N2+1N2ckejktf(t)\approx\sum_{k=-\frac{N}{2}+1}^{\frac{N}{2}}c_ke^{jkt} f(t)≈k=−2N​+1∑2N​​ck​ejkt

we have fk=f(k2πN),0≤k<Nf_k=f(k\frac{2\pi}{N}),0\le k<Nfk​=f(kN2π​),0≤k<N and so for each sample fkf_kfk​ we have fk=f(tk)=∑n=−N/2+1N/2cnejntkf_k=f(t_k)=\sum_{n=-N/2+1}^{N/2}c_ne^{jnt_k}fk​=f(tk​)=∑n=−N/2+1N/2​cn​ejntk​ where tk=2πNkt_k=\frac{2\pi}{N}ktk​=N2π​k. let W=e2πj/NW=e^{2\pi j/N}W=e2πj/N, after some algebra

fk=∑n=0N2cnWnk+∑n=−N2+1−1cnWnk=∑n=0N2cnWnk+∑n=−N2+1−1cnW(N+n)k(unity)=∑n=0N2cnWnk+∑n=N2+1Nc−nWnk\begin{aligned} f_k&=\sum_{n=0}^{\frac{N}{2}}c_nW^{nk}+\sum_{n=-\frac{N}{2}+1}^{-1}c_nW^{nk}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{\frac{N}{2}}c_nW^{nk}+\sum_{n=-\frac{N}{2}+1}^{-1}c_nW^{(N+n)k}\quad\text{(unity)}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{\frac{N}{2}}c_nW^{nk}+\sum_{n=\frac{N}{2}+1}^Nc_{-n}W^{nk} \end{aligned} fk​​=n=0∑2N​​cn​Wnk+n=−2N​+1∑−1​cn​Wnk=n=0∑2N​​cn​Wnk+n=−2N​+1∑−1​cn​W(N+n)k(unity)=n=0∑2N​​cn​Wnk+n=2N​+1∑N​c−n​Wnk​

we have

∣Fn∣=∣FN−n∣=∣c−n∣=∣cn∣|F_n|=|F_{N-n}|=|c_{-n}|=|c_n| ∣Fn​∣=∣FN−n​∣=∣c−n​∣=∣cn​∣

the fkf_kfk​ is then the inverse dft:

fk=∑n=0N−1WnkFnFk=∑n=0N−1W−nkfnf_k=\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}W^{nk}F_n\\F_k=\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}W^{-nk}f_n fk​=n=0∑N−1​WnkFn​Fk​=n=0∑N−1​W−nkfn​

note

  • high frequency in the middle
  • low frequency on both sides

Week 8. June 28

fast fourier transform

normally computing F0,...,FN−1F_0,...,F_{N-1}F0​,...,FN−1​ we require O(n^2) operations. now assume N is even, and further more is a power of 2. we can compute them in O(NlogN) steps.

observation. if W is an Nth root of unity, then W2W^2W2 is an N2\frac{N}{2}2N​ root of unity.

observation. if W is an Nth root of unity, then WN/2=−1W^{N/2}=-1WN/2=−1. hence we also have WkN/2=(−1)kW^{kN/2}=(-1)^kWkN/2=(−1)k.

we separate the computation into k=even terms and k=odd terms.

NFk=∑n=0N−1fnW−nk=∑n=0N/2−1fnW−nk+∑n=N/2N−1fnW−nk=∑n=0N/2−1fnW−nk+(W−(N/2)k)∑n=N/2N−1fnW−(n−N/2)k=∑n=0N/2−1fnW−nk+(−1)k∑n=N/2N−1fnW−(n−N/2)k\begin{aligned} NF_k&=\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}f_nW^{-nk}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}f_nW^{-nk}+\sum_{n=N/2}^{N-1}f_nW^{-nk}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}f_nW^{-nk}+(W^{-(N/2)k})\sum_{n=N/2}^{N-1}f_nW^{-(n-N/2)k}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}f_nW^{-nk}+(-1)^k\sum_{n=N/2}^{N-1}f_nW^{-(n-N/2)k}\\ \end{aligned} NFk​​=n=0∑N−1​fn​W−nk=n=0∑N/2−1​fn​W−nk+n=N/2∑N−1​fn​W−nk=n=0∑N/2−1​fn​W−nk+(W−(N/2)k)n=N/2∑N−1​fn​W−(n−N/2)k=n=0∑N/2−1​fn​W−nk+(−1)kn=N/2∑N−1​fn​W−(n−N/2)k​

when k=2k is even, (−1)k=1(-1)^k=1(−1)k=1, otherwise k=2k+1 (−1)k=−1(-1)^k=-1(−1)k=−1, let U=W2U=W^2U=W2, so

N2F2k=∑n=0N/2−1fnW−2nk+∑n=N/2N−1fnW−(n−N/2)2k=∑n=0N/2−1fnU−nk+∑n=N/2N−1fnU−(n−N/2)k=∑n=0N/2−1(fn+fN/2+n)U−(n−N/2)k\begin{aligned} \frac{N}{2}F_{2k}&=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}f_nW^{-2nk}+\sum_{n=N/2}^{N-1}f_nW^{-(n-N/2)2k}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}f_nU^{-nk}+\sum_{n=N/2}^{N-1}f_nU^{-(n-N/2)k}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}(f_n+f_{N/2+n})U^{-(n-N/2)k} \end{aligned} 2N​F2k​​=n=0∑N/2−1​fn​W−2nk+n=N/2∑N−1​fn​W−(n−N/2)2k=n=0∑N/2−1​fn​U−nk+n=N/2∑N−1​fn​U−(n−N/2)k=n=0∑N/2−1​(fn​+fN/2+n​)U−(n−N/2)k​

N2F2k+1=∑n=0N/2−1fnW−n(2k+1)−∑n=N/2N−1fnW−(n−N/2)(2k+1)=∑n=0N/2−1fnW−nU−nk−∑n=N/2N−1fnW−nU−(n−N/2)k=∑n=0N/2−1(fn−fN/2+n)W−nU−(n−N/2)k\begin{aligned} \frac{N}{2}F_{2k+1}&=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}f_nW^{-n(2k+1)}-\sum_{n=N/2}^{N-1}f_nW^{-(n-N/2)(2k+1)}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}f_nW^{-n}U^{-nk}-\sum_{n=N/2}^{N-1}f_nW^{-n}U^{-(n-N/2)k}\\ &=\sum_{n=0}^{N/2-1}(f_n-f_{N/2+n})W^{-n}U^{-(n-N/2)k} \end{aligned} 2N​F2k+1​​=n=0∑N/2−1​fn​W−n(2k+1)−n=N/2∑N−1​fn​W−(n−N/2)(2k+1)=n=0∑N/2−1​fn​W−nU−nk−n=N/2∑N−1​fn​W−nU−(n−N/2)k=n=0∑N/2−1​(fn​−fN/2+n​)W−nU−(n−N/2)k​

the fourier transform can be divided into even and odd terms' fourier transforms.

algo.

define two sequences of length N/2:

gk=fk+fN/2+k2hk=fk−fN/2+k2W−kg_k=\frac{f_k+f_{N/2+k}}{2}\\ h_k=\frac{f_k-f_{N/2+k}}{2}W^{-k} gk​=2fk​+fN/2+k​​hk​=2fk​−fN/2+k​​W−k

  1. compute fourier transform of g0,...,gN/2−1g_0,...,g_{N/2-1}g0​,...,gN/2−1​ to get G0,...,GN/2−1G_0,...,G_{N/2-1}G0​,...,GN/2−1​
  2. compute fourier transform of h0,...,hN/2−1h_0,...,h_{N/2-1}h0​,...,hN/2−1​ to get H0,...,HN/2−1H_0,...,H_{N/2-1}H0​,...,HN/2−1​
  3. then F2k=Gk,F2k+1=HkF_{2k}=G_k,F_{2k+1}=H_kF2k​=Gk​,F2k+1​=Hk​
    • ie output F0,F1,...,FN−1=G0,H0,G1,H1,...,GN/2−1,HN/2−1F_0,F_1,...,F_{N-1}=G_0,H_0,G_1,H_1,...,G_{N/2-1},H_{N/2-1}F0​,F1​,...,FN−1​=G0​,H0​,G1​,H1​,...,GN/2−1​,HN/2−1​

cost: C(N) = 2C(N/2) + cN => O(NlogN)

butterfly algorithm (inplace fft):

f[n]  ------->  f[n] + f[n+N/2]
      \     ^
       \   /
        \ /
         \
        / \
       /   \
      /     v
f[n+N/2] ----> f[n+N/2] - f[n+N/2]

var N = 2 ** m
var W = e ** (2*j*pi / N)
for k = 1, m:
    for j = 1, 2**(k-1):
        var v = (j - 1) * N
        for n = 0, N / 2 - 1:
            var wf = W ** -n
            var temp = wf * (f[n] - f[n + N/2])
            f[n + v] = 1/2 * (f[n] + f[n + N/2])
            f[n + v + N/2] = temp / 2
    N /= 2
output in reverse binary form // (for 8 nums, F[1] => F[0b001] => F[0b100] => F[4])

signal filtering

basic idea:

  • transform time/space data into frequencies via fft
  • manipulate data in frequency domain
  • transform frequency data into time/space data via inverse dft

eg. given signal 1: sound of both trains and bird sounds. we would like to decompose it into

  • signal 2 train whistle sounds: low frequency
  • signal 3 bird sounds: high frequency

correlating two signals

then we want to find M and L such that

  • region 1: FM<...<FM+N/2F_M<...<F_{M+N/2}FM​<...<FM+N/2​ for middle region of high frequencies
  • region 2: ...<FL,FN−L<......<F_L, F_{N-L}<......<FL​,FN−L​<... for start and end regions of low frequencies.

defn. given two signals y0,...,yN−1y_0,...,y_{N-1}y0​,...,yN−1​ and z0,...,zN−1z_0,...,z_{N-1}z0​,...,zN−1​, the correlation function is ϕk=1N∑n=0Nyn+kzn,k=0,...,N−1\phi_k=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^Ny_{n+k}z_n,k=0,...,N-1ϕk​=N1​∑n=0N​yn+k​zn​,k=0,...,N−1.

  • typically we want to find the index k such that ϕk\phi_kϕk​ is maximized.
  • if k = n is the maximum value then shifting by n positions gives the best match of data.

wrap-around effects:

  • correlation assumes two signals are periodic. in practice, input data are not often periodic, giving wrap-around effects
  • to avoid wrap-around pollution, we pad both arrays with zeros up to twice their original length
  • padding zeros does not change offset

typically computing correlation takes O(n^2). however we can convert the computation into fourier transform:

algo.

  1. compute fourier transform of y0,...,yN−1y_0,...,y_{N-1}y0​,...,yN−1​ to get Y0,...,YN−1Y_0,...,Y_{N-1}Y0​,...,YN−1​
  2. compute fourier transform of z0,...,zN−1z_0,...,z_{N-1}z0​,...,zN−1​ to get Z0,...,ZN−1Z_0,...,Z_{N-1}Z0​,...,ZN−1​
  3. multiply Φk=YkZk‾\Phi_k=Y_k\overline{Z_k}Φk​=Yk​Zk​​
  4. compute inverse ft of Φ0,...,ΦN−1\Phi_0,...,\Phi_{N-1}Φ0​,...,ΦN−1​ to get ϕ0,...,ϕN−1\phi_0,...,\phi_{N-1}ϕ0​,...,ϕN−1​

proof.

let Φk\Phi_kΦk​ be the ft of ϕk\phi_kϕk​, we have Φk=1N∑n=0N−1ϕnW−nk=1N2∑n=0N−1∑u=0N−1yu+nzuW−nk\Phi_k=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\phi_nW^{-nk}=\frac{1}{N^2}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\sum_{u=0}^{N-1}y_{u+n}z_uW^{-nk}Φk​=N1​∑n=0N−1​ϕn​W−nk=N21​∑n=0N−1​∑u=0N−1​yu+n​zu​W−nk.

let yu+n=∑s=0N−1YsWs(u+n)y_{u+n}=\sum_{s=0}^{N-1}Y_sW^{s(u+n)}yu+n​=∑s=0N−1​Ys​Ws(u+n), zu=∑v=0N−1ZvWvuz_u=\sum_{v=0}^{N-1}Z_vW^{vu}zu​=∑v=0N−1​Zv​Wvu, then

Φk=1N2∑n=0N−1∑u=0N−1∑s=0N−1YsW(u+n)s∑v=0N−1ZvWvuW−nk=1N2∑S=0N−1Ys∑v=0N−1Zv∑n=0N−1∑u=0N−1 Wu(s+v)Wn(s−k)=1N2∑s=0N−1Ys∑v=0N−1Zv∑u=0N−1 Wu(s+v)∑n=0N−1 Wn(s−k)=1N∑s=0N−1Ys∑v=0N−1Zv∑u=0N−1 Wu(s+v)δs,k=1NYk∑v=0N−1Zv∑u=0N−1 Wu(k+v)=Yk∑v=0N−1Zvδv,N−k=YkZN−k=YkZk‾\begin{aligned} &\Phi_{{k}}=\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} \sum_{u=0}^{N-1} \sum_{s=0}^{N-1} Y_{{s}} {W}^{(u+{n}) {s}} \sum_{v=0}^{N-1} Z_{{v}} {W}^{{vu}} {W}^{-{nk}} \\ &=\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{S=0}^{N-1} Y_{{s}} \sum_{v=0}^{N-1} Z_{{v}} \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} \sum_{u=0}^{N-1} {~W}^{{u}({s}+{v})} {W}^{{n}({s}-{k})} \\ &=\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{s=0}^{N-1} Y_{{s}} \sum_{v=0}^{N-1} Z_{{v}} \sum_{u=0}^{N-1} {~W}^{{u}({s}+{v})} \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} {~W}^{{n}({s}-{k})} \\ &=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{s=0}^{N-1} Y_{{s}} \sum_{v=0}^{N-1} Z_{{v}} \sum_{u=0}^{N-1} {~W}^{{u}({s}+{v})} \delta_{{s}, {k}} \\ &=\frac{1}{N} {Y}_{{k}} \sum_{v=0}^{N-1} Z_{{v}} \sum_{u=0}^{N-1} {~W}^{{u}({k}+{v})} \\ &={Y}_{{k}} \sum_{v=0}^{N-1} Z_{{v}} \delta_{{v}, {N}-{k}} \\ &={Y}_{{k}} {Z}_{{N}-{k}} \\ &={Y}_{{k}} \overline{{Z}_{{k}}} \end{aligned} ​Φk​=N21​n=0∑N−1​u=0∑N−1​s=0∑N−1​Ys​W(u+n)sv=0∑N−1​Zv​WvuW−nk=N21​S=0∑N−1​Ys​v=0∑N−1​Zv​n=0∑N−1​u=0∑N−1​ Wu(s+v)Wn(s−k)=N21​s=0∑N−1​Ys​v=0∑N−1​Zv​u=0∑N−1​ Wu(s+v)n=0∑N−1​ Wn(s−k)=N1​s=0∑N−1​Ys​v=0∑N−1​Zv​u=0∑N−1​ Wu(s+v)δs,k​=N1​Yk​v=0∑N−1​Zv​u=0∑N−1​ Wu(k+v)=Yk​v=0∑N−1​Zv​δv,N−k​=Yk​ZN−k​=Yk​Zk​​​

where δs,k\delta_{s,k}δs,k​ = 1, when s = k, 0 otherwise. □\square□

signal aliasing

defn. fourier frequency is the number of cycles per second = kT=kFSN\frac{k}{T}=\frac{kF_S}{N}Tk​=NkFS​​, where sampling rate FS=NTF_S=\frac{N}{T}FS​=TN​ = number of discrete samples per second.

if a real input signal contains high frequencies, but the spacing of discretely sampled data points is inadequate, then aliasing occur.

(wagon-wheel effect; stationary rotor of helicopter)

recall for fk=f(k2πN)f_k=f(k\frac{2\pi}{N})fk​=f(kN2π​), we have Fk=ck+ck+N+ck−N+ck+2N+ck−2N+...F_k=c_k+c_{k+N}+c_{k-N}+c_{k+2N}+c_{k-2N}+...Fk​=ck​+ck+N​+ck−N​+ck+2N​+ck−2N​+..., sums of true continuous fourier series coefficients ckc_kck​ of increasing frequency. so frequencies ckc_kck​ for ∣k∣>N2|k|>\frac{N}{2}∣k∣>2N​ get aliased to lower frequencies. (?)

to avoid aliasing:

  • increase sampling resolution to capture higher frequencies
  • filter before sampling to remove (too) high frequencies so they do not cause aliasing

data compression

consider 1D array of greyscale.

a dominant pattern appears 4 times, so F4F_4F4​ is large. we can discard data with less frequencies.

1D compression strategy:

  • create an (approximate) compressed version of the image fnf_nfn​ by throwing away f∗f^*f∗ 'small' fourier coefficients such that ∣Fk∣|F_k|∣Fk​∣ < TOL
  • run inverse dft to get modified pixels fn∗f^*_nfn∗​ to reconstruct the image
  • discard imaginary parts of fn∗f^*_nfn∗​ to ensure new data is strictly real

image processing in 2D

consider 2D image in grey scale with a 2D array X with MN pixels. assume data is scaled so that 0≤X(i,j)≤10\le X(i,j)\le 10≤X(i,j)≤1.

we move from time/space domain to frequency domain using 2D dft:

Fj,k=1MN∑n=0N−1∑m=0M−1fn,mWN−nkWM−mj=1N∑n=0N−1WN−nk(1M∑m=0M−1fn,mWM−mj)(DFT per row)\begin{aligned} F_{j,k}&=\frac{1}{MN}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}\sum_{m=0}^{M-1}f_{n,m}W_N^{-nk}W_M^{-mj}\\ &=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}W_N^{-nk}\left(\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=0}^{M-1}f_{n,m}W_M^{-mj}\right)\quad\text{(DFT per row)} \end{aligned} Fj,k​​=MN1​n=0∑N−1​m=0∑M−1​fn,m​WN−nk​WM−mj​=N1​n=0∑N−1​WN−nk​(M1​m=0∑M−1​fn,m​WM−mj​)(DFT per row)​

where WNW_NWN​ is Nth root of unity and WMW_MWM​ is Mth root of unity.

the 2D FFT can be computed efficiently using nested 1D FFTs:

  1. transform each row (separately) using 1D fft
  2. transform each column of the result using 1D fft

complexity: O(MN(log⁡M+log⁡N))O(MN(\log M+\log N))O(MN(logM+logN)).

JPEG

  1. break down image into 8x8 blocks - image does not change very much in such small block
  2. transform each block from spatial to frequency domain using 2D discrete cosine transform
    • Fu,v=c∑n=07∑m=07fn,mcos⁡2n+116πu⋅cos⁡2m+116πvF_{u,v}=c\sum_{n=0}^7\sum_{m=0}^7f_{n,m}\cos\frac{2n+1}{16}\pi u \cdot\cos\frac{2m+1}{16}\pi vFu,v​=c∑n=07​∑m=07​fn,m​cos162n+1​πu⋅cos162m+1​πv
    • helps separate image into parts of differing importance
  3. reduce blocks in order to reduce size of higher frequencies
    • keep F[0,0] separate (DC component)
    • then reduce size of all other components via quantization table Q
      • Fnew[j,k] = round(F[j,k] / Q[j,k])
    • then reduce higher frequency values more ie discard unnecessary info
  4. entropy encoding: treat DC component separate since it is usually large. save first value then determine difference for each block afterwards
  5. convert 2D array into 1D array using a zigzag pattern - compress by skipping 0 continuous values

Week 11. July 19

linear algebra

solving system of linear equations

recall:

  • elementary matrix is identity matrix with single row operation
  • row operations are same as multiplication on the left by elementary matrix

given nonsigular matrix A and vector b\mathbf{b}b, solve Ax=bA\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}Ax=b for x\mathbf{x}x.

steps:

  1. LU decomposition: factor A into A=LUA = LUA=LU where L is lower triangular and U is upper triangular
    • do gaussian elimination on A keeping operations in L
      • if E1,...,EnE_1,...,E_nE1​,...,En​ are some row operations, then to get an upper triangular U matrix from A, we did En...E1A=UE_n...E_1A=UEn​...E1​A=U. then A=(En...E1)−1U=(E1−1...En−1)U=:LUA=(E_n...E_1)^{-1}U=(E_1^{-1}...E_n^{-1})U=:LUA=(En​...E1​)−1U=(E1−1​...En−1​)U=:LU.
  2. solve Ly=bL\mathbf{y}=\mathbf{b}Ly=b
    • apply same operations to b\mathbf{b}b getting result y\mathbf{y}y (forward solve)
  3. solve Ux=yU\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{y}Ux=y
    • (backward solve)

eg. solve Ax=b:

[123456781][x1x2x3]=[44−4]\begin{bmatrix} 1&2&3 \\ 4&5&6 \\ 7&8&1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1\\x_2\\x_3 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 4\\4\\-4 \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​147​258​361​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​x1​x2​x3​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​44−4​⎦⎤​

first perform factorization A=LU:

[123456781]=[100410721][1230−3−600−8]\begin{bmatrix} 1&2&3 \\ 4&5&6 \\ 7&8&1 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 1&0&0 \\ 4&1&0 \\ 7&2&1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1&2&3 \\ 0&-3&-6 \\ 0&0&-8 \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​147​258​361​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​147​012​001​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​100​2−30​3−6−8​⎦⎤​

then solve Ly=b:

[100410721][y1y2y3]=[44−4]\begin{bmatrix} 1&0&0 \\ 4&1&0 \\ 7&2&1 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ y_3 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 4\\4\\-4 \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​147​012​001​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​y1​y2​y3​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​44−4​⎦⎤​

note we can get y1=4y_1=4y1​=4 directly, then use this to compute y2y_2y2​, then use them to compute y3y_3y3​. we have yT=[4,−12,−8]\mathbf{y}^T=[4,-12,-8]yT=[4,−12,−8].

finally solve Ux=y:

[1230−3−600−8][x1x2x3]=[4−12−8]\begin{bmatrix} 1&2&3 \\ 0&-3&-6 \\ 0&0&-8 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 4\\ -12\\-8 \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​100​2−30​3−6−8​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​x1​x2​x3​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​4−12−8​⎦⎤​

note we get x3=1x_3=1x3​=1 directly, then use this to compute x2x_2x2​, then use them to compute x1x_1x1​. we have xT=[−3,2,1]\mathbf{x}^T=[-3,2,1]xT=[−3,2,1].

cost:

  • factoring A=LU
    • for first column of A, do row operations to eliminate 2nd to last elements; for second column, eliminate 3rd to last elements, etc. in total (n−1)2+(n−2)2+...+1+0=(n−1)n(2n−1)6=13n3+O(n2)(n-1)^2+(n-2)^2+...+1+0=\frac{(n-1)n(2n-1)}{6}=\frac{1}{3}n^3+O(n^2)(n−1)2+(n−2)2+...+1+0=6(n−1)n(2n−1)​=31​n3+O(n2) ops.
  • forward solve: 1+2+...+(n−1)=(n−1)n2=n22+O(n)1+2+...+(n-1)=\frac{(n-1)n}{2}=\frac{n^2}{2}+O(n)1+2+...+(n−1)=2(n−1)n​=2n2​+O(n)
  • backward solve: same as forward solve

PLU decomposition

LU decomposition does not work when pivot is 0 => we have 0 on diagonal and we need to swap rows to preceed.

[0451−233−23069]⇒[−233−204513069]\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 0 & 4 & 5 & 1 \\ -2 & 3 & 3 & -2 \\ 3 & 0 & 6 & 9 \end{array}\right]\Rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} -2 & 3 & 3 & -2 \\ 0 & 4 & 5 & 1 \\ 3 & 0 & 6 & 9 \end{array}\right] ⎣⎡​0−23​430​536​1−29​⎦⎤​⇒⎣⎡​−203​340​356​−219​⎦⎤​

we need to permute rows => a permutation matrix P so that PA = LU.

steps:

  1. PLU decomposition: factor A into PA=LUPA = LUPA=LU where L is lower triangular and U is upper triangular
  2. solve Ly=b′L\mathbf{y}=\mathbf{b'}Ly=b′ (b': permuted version of b)
  3. solve Ux=yU\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{y}Ux=y

start with P set to nxn identity matrix I. whenever we swap a pair of rows during LU factorization, also swap corresponding rows of P, the final P is the permutation matrix (in implementation, we do not store P explicitly).

what happens when pivot is nearly 0? forming aikakk\frac{a_{ik}}{a_{kk}}akk​aik​​ gives number of large magnitude, causing large float point error during subtraction and magnify existing error.

partial pivoting strategy: find the row with entry having largest magnitude in current column beneath current row. swap rows if its entry has larger magnitude than diagonal entry.

eg. consider in 4-digit arithmetic.

{10−5x+y=1x+y=2\left\{\begin{matrix} 10^{-5}x+y=1\\ x+y=2 \end{matrix}\right. {10−5x+y=1x+y=2​

pivot is 10−510^{-5}10−5. multiple first row by 10510^{5}105 we have (1−105)y=2−105⇒(105−1)y=105−2⇒99999y=99998⇒9999y=9999(1-10^5)y=2-10^5\Rightarrow (10^5-1)y=10^5-2\Rightarrow 99999y=99998\Rightarrow 9999y=9999(1−105)y=2−105⇒(105−1)y=105−2⇒99999y=99998⇒9999y=9999 (truncation) so y=1y=1y=1 and x=0x=0x=0.

if we switch rows, the pivot is 1

{x+y=210−5x+y=1\left\{\begin{matrix} x+y=2\\ 10^{-5}x+y=1\\ \end{matrix}\right. {x+y=210−5x+y=1​

and (1−10−5)y=1−2⋅10−5⇒y=1,x=1(1-10^{-5})y=1-2\cdot10^{-5}\Rightarrow y=1,x=1(1−10−5)y=1−2⋅10−5⇒y=1,x=1 which is better solution.

Week 12. July 26

conditioning of matrix

we want to recognize when matrix might be ill-formed for solving. this is what would happen if we get one answer for solving Ax=b but significantly different answer when we perturb b slightly. we want to measure the matrix A.

defn. ∣∣⋅∣∣||\cdot||∣∣⋅∣∣ is a matrix norm if

  1. ∣∣A∣∣≥0||A||\geq 0∣∣A∣∣≥0 and ∣∣A∣∣=0  ⟺  A=0||A||=0\iff A=0∣∣A∣∣=0⟺A=0
  2. ∣∣cA∣∣=∣c∣∣∣A∣∣||cA||=|c|||A||∣∣cA∣∣=∣c∣∣∣A∣∣ for any scalar c
  3. ∣∣A+B∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣+∣∣B∣∣||A+B||\leq||A||+||B||∣∣A+B∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣+∣∣B∣∣ (triangle inequality)
  4. ∣∣AB∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣B∣∣||AB||\leq ||A||\cdot||B||∣∣AB∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣B∣∣ (show by using 4.)
  5. ∣∣Av∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣v∣∣||A\mathbf{v}||\leq||A||\cdot||\mathbf{v}||∣∣Av∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣v∣∣ (obvious from following defn)
  6. ∣∣In∣∣=1||I_n||=1∣∣In​∣∣=1

defn. if ∣∣ ∣∣||\,||∣∣∣∣ is a vector form then we can define a matrix norm by ∣∣A∣∣=max⁡x≠0∣∣Ax∣∣∣∣x∣∣||A||=\max_{\mathbf{x}\neq \mathbf{0}}\frac{||A\mathbf{x}||}{||\mathbf{x}||}∣∣A∣∣=maxx=0​∣∣x∣∣∣∣Ax∣∣​ for any vector x\mathbf{x}x.

prop.

  • ∣∣A∣∣1=max⁡j∑i=1n∣Aij∣||A||_1=\max_j\sum_{i=1}^n|A_{ij}|∣∣A∣∣1​=maxj​∑i=1n​∣Aij​∣ = maximum column sum
  • ∣∣A∣∣2=∣λ∣||A||_2=\sqrt{|\lambda|}∣∣A∣∣2​=∣λ∣​ where λ\lambdaλ is largest eigenvalue of AA⊺AA^\intercalAA⊺
  • ∣∣A∣∣∞=max⁡i∑j=1n∣Aij∣||A||_\infty=\max_i\sum_{j=1}^n|A_{ij}|∣∣A∣∣∞​=maxi​∑j=1n​∣Aij​∣ = maximum row sum

when we work in float point environment we get Axnum=bnumA\mathbf{x}^\mathrm{num}=\mathbf{b}^\mathrm{num}Axnum=bnum. having accurate solution means we want small ∣∣Δx∣∣∣∣x∣∣\frac{||\Delta \mathbf{x}||}{||\mathbf{x}||}∣∣x∣∣∣∣Δx∣∣​ where Δx=xexact−xnum\Delta\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}^\mathrm{exact}-\mathbf{x}^\mathrm{num}Δx=xexact−xnum, however we cannot measure this relative error because we do not know the exact solution. we can measure the residual ∣∣Δb∣∣∣∣b∣∣\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{b}||}{||\mathbf{b}||}∣∣b∣∣∣∣Δb∣∣​ where Δb=bexact−bnum\Delta\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{b}^\mathrm{exact}-\mathbf{b}^\mathrm{num}Δb=bexact−bnum. we want to connect them.

to determine accuracy we want to estimate:

  • relative change in x\mathbf{x}x due to relative change in b\mathbf{b}b: ∣∣Δx∣∣∣∣x∣∣≤(∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣A−1∣∣)∣∣Δb∣∣∣∣b∣∣\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{x}||}{||\mathbf{x}||}\leq(||A||\cdot||A^{-1}||)\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{b}||}{||\mathbf{b}||}∣∣x∣∣∣∣Δx∣∣​≤(∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣A−1∣∣)∣∣b∣∣∣∣Δb∣∣​
    • proof. note we have AΔx=Δb  ⟹  Δx=A−1Δb  ⟹  ∣∣Δx∣∣=∣∣A−1Δb∣∣≤∣∣A−1∣∣∣∣Δb∣∣A\Delta\mathbf{x}=\Delta\mathbf{b}\implies \Delta\mathbf{x}=A^{-1}\Delta\mathbf{b}\implies||\Delta\mathbf{x}||=||A^{-1}\Delta\mathbf{b}||\leq||A^{-1}||||\Delta\mathbf{b}||AΔx=Δb⟹Δx=A−1Δb⟹∣∣Δx∣∣=∣∣A−1Δb∣∣≤∣∣A−1∣∣∣∣Δb∣∣. also ∣∣b∣∣=∣∣Ax∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣∣∣x∣∣  ⟹  1∣∣x∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣∣∣b∣∣||\mathbf{b}||=||A\mathbf{x}||\leq||A||||\mathbf{x}||\implies \frac{1}{||\mathbf{x}||}\leq\frac{||A||}{||\mathbf{b}||}∣∣b∣∣=∣∣Ax∣∣≤∣∣A∣∣∣∣x∣∣⟹∣∣x∣∣1​≤∣∣b∣∣∣∣A∣∣​. □\square□
  • relative change in x\mathbf{x}x due to change in AAA: ∣∣Δx∣∣∣∣x+Δx∣∣≤(∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣A−1∣∣)∣∣ΔA∣∣∣∣A∣∣\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{x}||}{||\mathbf{x}+\Delta\mathbf{x}||}\leq(||A||\cdot||A^{-1}||)\frac{||\Delta A||}{||A||}∣∣x+Δx∣∣∣∣Δx∣∣​≤(∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣A−1∣∣)∣∣A∣∣∣∣ΔA∣∣​ (how to show?)

defn. the condition number of matrix A is denoted κ(A)=∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣A−1∣∣\kappa(A)=||A||\cdot||A^{-1}||κ(A)=∣∣A∣∣⋅∣∣A−1∣∣.

  • different for different matrix norms
  • κ≈1\kappa\approx1κ≈1: A is well-conditioned
  • κ≫1\kappa\gg1κ≫1: A is ill-conditioned

suppose κ(A)≈βq\kappa(A)\approx\beta^qκ(A)≈βq, from ∣∣Δx∣∣∣∣x∣∣≤κ(A)∣∣Δb∣∣∣∣b∣∣\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{x}||}{||\mathbf{x}||}\leq\kappa(A)\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{b}||}{||\mathbf{b}||}∣∣x∣∣∣∣Δx∣∣​≤κ(A)∣∣b∣∣∣∣Δb∣∣​ we estimate

  • relative error ∣∣Δb∣∣b\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{b}||}{\mathbf{b}}b∣∣Δb∣∣​ is at level of roundoff error - eg β1−t\beta^{1-t}β1−t ie last digit.
  • so relative error ∣∣Δx∣∣x\frac{||\Delta\mathbf{x}||}{\mathbf{x}}x∣∣Δx∣∣​ magnifies this by βq\beta^qβq and so is around βq+1−t\beta^{q+1-t}βq+1−t ie last q digits.

improving solutions:

recall we wanted Ax=bA\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{b}Ax=b but get Axnum=bnumA\mathbf{x}^\mathrm{num}=\mathrm{b}^\mathrm{num}Axnum=bnum, now x=xnum+Δx\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}^\mathrm{num}+\Delta\mathbf{x}x=xnum+Δx and b=bnum+Δb\mathbf{b}=\mathbf{b}^\mathrm{num}+\Delta\mathbf{b}b=bnum+Δb so AΔx=ΔbA\Delta\mathbf{x}=\Delta\mathbf{b}AΔx=Δb. we can solve this equation (cheap as we have done row reduction for A) to get estimate for Δx\Delta\mathbf{x}Δx. then xnew=x+Δx\mathbf{x}^\mathrm{new}=\mathbf{x}+\Delta\mathbf{x}xnew=x+Δx is an improved solution.

page rank

we represent web's structure as a directed graph. nodes represent pages, arcs represent links from one page to another. (out)degree of a node is defined as number of edges leaving that node. web is stored as an adjacency matrix (the degree of node is sum of its column).

local importance: we interpret links as votes: if page j links to page i, this is considered a vote by j that i is important. outgoing links of a page j have equal influence, so the importance that j gives to i is 1deg(j)\frac{1}{\mathrm{deg}(j)}deg(j)1​.

         2 -----------+
                      v
+-------------------- 4
v                     |
5 ------------> 6 <---+

page 4 gives importance of 1/2 to page 5

so if page i has many incoming links, it is probably important.

global importance: what if page j only has one link to it but that page is important? => a node is important if important nodes link to it (this is a bit recursive)

ranking by random surfer model:

  • user starts at random page (with all pages equally likely) and follows links at random for k steps
  • user will probably end up on important pages more often
  • select new start page and follow k random links again. repeat r times.
  • at the end, we estimate overall importance as Rank(page i)=# visits to i# visits\mathrm{Rank}(\text{page }i) =\frac{\text{\# visits to }i}{\text{\# visits}}Rank(page i)=# visits# visits to i​

issues:

  • large size of web: many pages and links, many iterations
  • number of steps taken per random surf sequence must be large
  • major issue: dead end links (stuck on one page)
  • major issue: cycles in graph (stuck in a closed subset of pages)

we can view actions of random surfer as transition matrix on the web

defn. if the surfer is at node i then all outnodes are equally likely, we define

Pij={1deg(j),link j to i exists0,elseP_{ij}=\left\{\begin{matrix} \frac{1}{\mathrm{deg}(j)},&\text{link }j\text{ to }i\text{ exists}\\ 0,&\text{else} \end{matrix}\right. Pij​={deg(j)1​,0,​link j to i existselse​

then probability that the random surfer is at node i after k steps is mi(k)=∑j=1RPijmj(k−1)m_i^{(k)}=\sum_{j=1}^R P_{ij}m_j^{(k-1)}mi(k)​=∑j=1R​Pij​mj(k−1)​.

defn. let e=[1,...,1]⊺\mathbf{e}=[1,...,1]^\intercale=[1,...,1]⊺ and d=[d1,...,dR]⊺\mathbf{d}=[d_1,...,d_R]^\intercald=[d1​,...,dR​]⊺ where di=1d_i=1di​=1 if i is a dead end node, then 1Red⊺\frac{1}{R}\mathbf{e}\mathbf{d}^\intercalR1​ed⊺ is a matrix of probabilities which transitions from a dead end node to any other node with equal probability.

  • we add this to P so it it possible to avoid being stuck at a dead end node

defn. let e=[1,...,1]⊺\mathbf{e}=[1,...,1]^\intercale=[1,...,1]⊺, then 1Ree⊺\frac{1}{R}\mathbf{e}\mathbf{e}^\intercalR1​ee⊺ is a matrix of probabilities which transitions to any other node with equal probability.

  • to restart and escape cycles

defn. we define google matrix as M=α(P+1Red⊺)+(1−α)1Ree⊺M=\alpha(P+\frac{1}{R}\mathbf{e}\mathbf{d}^\intercal)+(1-\alpha)\frac{1}{R}\mathbf{e}\mathbf{e}^\intercalM=α(P+R1​ed⊺)+(1−α)R1​ee⊺ where 0<α<10<\alpha<10<α<1. so

  • α\alphaα is fraction of time random surfer follows links and special action and dead end nodes
  • 1−α1-\alpha1−α is fraction of time random surfer restarts

property. (1) each element of M satisfies 0≤Mij≤10\leq M_{ij}\leq 10≤Mij​≤1, and columns of M all add to 1. so M is still a markov matrix.

property. (2) if x=[x1,...,xR]⊺\mathbf{x}=[x_1,...,x_R]^\intercalx=[x1​,...,xR​]⊺ sums to 1, then y=Mx\mathbf{y}=M\mathbf{x}y=Mx sums to 1.

property. (3) 1 is an eigenvalue of M, so Mx=1xM\mathbf{x}=1\mathbf{x}Mx=1x.
pf. note M⊺e=eM^\intercal\mathbf{e}=\mathbf{e}M⊺e=e. □\square□

property. (4) if λ1,...,λR\lambda_1,...,\lambda_Rλ1​,...,λR​ are eigenvalues of M then ∣λ1∣,...,∣λR∣≤1|\lambda_1|,...,|\lambda_R|\leq 1∣λ1​∣,...,∣λR​∣≤1.
proof. for each eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ, we have M⊺v=λvM^\intercal\mathbf{v}=\lambda\mathbf{v}M⊺v=λv for all v\mathbf{v}v. then for all i, m1iv1+...+mRivR=λvi  ⟹  ∣λvi∣≤m1i∣v1∣+...+mRi∣vR∣≤(m1i+...+m1R)max⁡1≤k≤R∣vk∣=1⋅max⁡1≤k≤R∣vk∣m_{1i}v_1+...+m_{Ri}v_R=\lambda v_i\implies|\lambda v_i|\leq m_{1i}|v_1|+...+m_{Ri}|v_R|\leq (m_{1i}+...+m_{1R})\max_{1\leq k\leq R}|v_k|=1\cdot\max_{1\leq k\leq R}|v_k|m1i​v1​+...+mRi​vR​=λvi​⟹∣λvi​∣≤m1i​∣v1​∣+...+mRi​∣vR​∣≤(m1i​+...+m1R​)max1≤k≤R​∣vk​∣=1⋅max1≤k≤R​∣vk​∣, so ∣λ∣≤∣vi∣max⁡1≤k≤R∣vk∣≤1|\lambda|\leq\frac{|v_i|}{\max_{1\leq k\leq R}|v_k|}\leq 1∣λ∣≤max1≤k≤R​∣vk​∣∣vi​∣​≤1. □\square□

property. (5) M has only one eigenvalue of length 1. all others are less than 1.

property. (6) if M has eigenvalues 1=λ1≥∣λ2∣≥...≥∣λR∣1=\lambda_1\geq|\lambda_2|\geq...\geq|\lambda_R|1=λ1​≥∣λ2​∣≥...≥∣λR​∣ and x(0)=[1R,...,1R]⊺\mathbf{x}^{(0)}=[\frac{1}{R},...,\frac{1}{R}]^\intercalx(0)=[R1​,...,R1​]⊺, then there are eigenvectors vi\mathbf{v}_ivi​ such that x(0)=∑i=1Rcivi\mathbf{x}^{(0)}=\sum_{i=1}^Rc_i\mathbf{v}_ix(0)=∑i=1R​ci​vi​.

page rank algorithm:

  1. let M=α(P+1Red⊺)+(1−α)1Ree⊺M=\alpha(P+\frac{1}{R}\mathbf{e}\mathbf{d}^\intercal)+(1-\alpha)\frac{1}{R}\mathbf{e}\mathbf{e}^\intercalM=α(P+R1​ed⊺)+(1−α)R1​ee⊺ where 0<α<10<\alpha<10<α<1
  2. let x(0)=[1R,...,1R]⊺\mathbf{x}^{(0)}=[\frac{1}{R},...,\frac{1}{R}]^\intercalx(0)=[R1​,...,R1​]⊺ (start with equal probs)
  3. for k = 1 to stopping criterion:
    1. x(k)=Mx(k−1)\mathbf{x}^{(k)}=M\mathbf{x}^{(k-1)}x(k)=Mx(k−1)
  4. ranking vector is then lim⁡k→∞x(k)=:x(∞)\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\mathbf{x}^{(k)}=:\mathbf{x}^{(\infty)}limk→∞​x(k)=:x(∞)
    • pages with more probability is more important
    • note eventually Mx(∞)=x(∞)M\mathbf{x}^{(\infty)}=\mathbf{x}^{(\infty)}Mx(∞)=x(∞), ie we are at a fixed point.

P is sparse while M is dense, but M is special and we can do MxM\mathbf{x}Mx without dense linear algebra,

  1. first do y=Px\mathbf{y}=P\mathbf{x}y=Px via sparse matrix multiplication, ie yi=pi1x1+...+pikxky_i=p_{i1}x_1+...+p_{ik}x_kyi​=pi1​x1​+...+pik​xk​
  2. similarly we include dead end pages directly via yi←yi+x1+...+xky_i\leftarrow y_i+x_1+...+x_kyi​←yi​+x1​+...+xk​
  3. so final y=Mx\mathbf{y}=M\mathbf{x}y=Mx has components yi=α(pi1x1+...+pikxk+x1+...+xk)+1−αRy_i=\alpha(p_{i1}x_1+...+p_{ik}x_k+x_1+...+x_k)+\frac{1-\alpha}{R}yi​=α(pi1​x1​+...+pik​xk​+x1​+...+xk​)+R1−α​

convergence: by using property 6, we have x(k)=c1v1+∑i=2Rciλikvi→c1v1\mathbf{x}^{(k)}=c_1\mathbf{v}_1+ \sum_{i=2}^Rc_i\lambda_i^k\mathbf{v}_i\rightarrow c_1\mathrm{v}_1x(k)=c1​v1​+∑i=2R​ci​λik​vi​→c1​v1​ as k→∞k\rightarrow\inftyk→∞. second eigenvalue tells us when to stop, and is λ2=α\lambda_2=\alphaλ2​=α. our stopping criterion is then ∣λ2∣k−1<ϵ|\lambda_2|^{k-1}<\epsilon∣λ2​∣k−1<ϵ. if we have precision 8 and α=.85\alpha=.85α=.85 we would stop at iteration 114.
